question_text:
Mosquitoes pose a threat to human health. Controlling mosquitoes using chemicals may have undesired consequences. In Florida, authorities have used genetically modified mosquitoes to control the overall mosquito population. It remains to be seen if this novel approach has unforeseen consequences.

Which one of the following is the correct logical inference based on the information in the above passage?

(a) Using chemicals to kill mosquitoes is better than using genetically modified mosquitoes because genetic engineering is dangerous (b) Using genetically modified mosquitoes is better than using chemicals to kill mosquitoes because they do not have any side effects

(c) Both using genetically modified mosquitoes and chemicals have undesired consequences and can be dangerous

(d) Using chemicals to kill mosquitoes may have undesired consequences but it is not clear if using genetically modified mosquitoes has any negative consequence
solution_text:
(d)

Using chemicals to kill mosquitoes may have undesired consequence but it is not clear if using genetically modified mosquitoes has any negative consequence.

subject: Aptitude
question_text:
Consider the following inequalities.

(i) $2 x-1>7$

(ii) $2 x-9<1$

Which one of the following expressions below satisfies the above two inequalities?
(a) $x \leq-4$
(b) $-4<x \leq 4$
(c) $4<x<5$
(d) $x \geq 5$
solution_text:
(c)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow 2 x-1>7 \mid \quad 2 x-9<1 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 2 x>8 \quad \Rightarrow \quad 2 x<10 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x>4 \quad \mid \Rightarrow \quad x<5
\end{aligned}
$$

Combining both inequalities

$4<x<5$

question_text:
Four points $\mathrm{P}(0,1), Q(0,-3), R(-2,-1)$, and $S(2$, $-1)$ represent the vertices of a quadrilateral.

What is the area enclosed by the quadrilateral?
(a) 4
(b) $4 \sqrt{2}$
(c) 8
(d) $8 \sqrt{2}$
solution_text:
(c)

[image1]

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{PS} & =\sqrt{(\sqrt{2})^{4}+(-2)^{2}} \\
& =\sqrt{2+4+2} \\
& =\sqrt{8} \\
\mathrm{SQ} & =\sqrt{4+4}=\sqrt{8} \\
\mathrm{SQ} & =\sqrt{4+4}=\sqrt{8} \\
\mathrm{QS} & =\sqrt{4+4}=\sqrt{8} \\
\mathrm{PQ} & =\sqrt{16}=4 \\
\mathrm{RS} & =\sqrt{16}=4 \\
\text { Area } & =\sqrt{8} \times \sqrt{8}=8 \text { units }
\end{aligned}
$$

question_text:
Consider the two-dimensional vector field $\vec{F}(x, y)=x \vec{i}+y \vec{j}$, where $\vec{i}$ and $\vec{j}$ denote the unit vectors along the $x$-axis and the $y$-axis, respectively. A contour $C$ in the $x$-y plane, as shown in the figure, is composed of two horizontal lines connected at the two ends by two semicircular arcs of unit radius. The contour is traversed in the counter-clockwise sense. The value of the closed path integral $\oint \vec{F}(x, y) .(d x \vec{i}+d y \vec{j})$ is. $\qquad$

[image1]
(a) 0
(b) 1
(c) $8+2 \pi$
(d) -1
solution_text:
(a)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \oint \vec{F}(x, y) \cdot[d x \vec{i}+d y \vec{j}] \\
& \text { Given } \vec{F}(x, y)=x \vec{i}+y \vec{j} \\
& \therefore \quad \int_{c} x d x+y d y=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Because here vector is conservative.

If the integral function is the total derivative over the closed contoure then it will be zero.

question_text:
The current I in the circuit shown is $\qquad$

[image1]
(a) $1.25 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~A}$
(b) $0.75 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~A}$
(c) $-0.5 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~A}$
(d) $1.16 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~A}$
solution_text:
(b)

[image1]

Applying Nodal equation at Node-A

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{A}}}{2 \mathrm{k}}+\frac{\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{A}}-5}{2 \mathrm{k}}=10^{-3} \\
& \Rightarrow 2 \mathrm{~V}_{\mathrm{A}}-5=2 \mathrm{k} \times 10^{-3} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{A}}=\frac{7}{2} \mathrm{~V}=3.5 \mathrm{~V}
\end{aligned}
$$

Again,

$\mathrm{I}=\frac{5-\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{A}}}{2 \mathrm{k}}=\frac{5-3.5}{2 \mathrm{k}}=\frac{1.5}{2 \mathrm{k}}=0.75 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~A}$

question_text:
Consider the CMOS circuit shown in the figure (substrates are connected to their respective sources). The gate width (W) to gate length ( $\mathrm{L}$ ) ratios $\left(\frac{\mathrm{W}}{\mathrm{L}}\right)$ of the transistors are as shown. Both the transistors have the same gate oxide capacitance per unit area. For the pMOSFET, the threshold voltage is $-1 \mathrm{~V}$ and the mobility of holes is $40 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} N$.s. For the nMOSFET, the threshold voltage is $1 \mathrm{~V}$ and the mobility of electrons is $300 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} N$.s. The steady state output voltage $\mathrm{V}_{0}$ is $\qquad$ .

[image1]
(a) equal to $0 \mathrm{~V}$
(b) more than $2 \mathrm{~V}$
(c) less than $2 \mathrm{~V}$
(d) equal to $2 \mathrm{~V}$

\section*{
solution_text:
(c)}

Figure.

Given data : $\left|V_{T P}\right|=1 V=V_{T N}$

$\mathrm{CO}_{\mathrm{x}}=$ equal

$\mu_{\mathrm{n}}=300$

$\mu_{\mathrm{P}}=40$

$I_{D 1}=I_{D 2}$

[image1]

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mu_{\mathrm{P}} \mathrm{CO}_{x}\left(\frac{\omega}{\mathrm{L}}\right)_{1}\left[4-\mathrm{V}_{0}-1\right]^{2}=\mu_{\mathrm{n}} \mathrm{CO}_{x}\left(\frac{\omega}{\mathrm{L}}\right)_{2}\left[\mathrm{~V}_{0}-0-1\right]^{2} \\
& \Rightarrow \frac{300}{40} \times \frac{1}{5}\left(\mathrm{~V}_{0}-1\right)^{2}=\left(3-\mathrm{V}_{0}\right)^{2} \\
& \Rightarrow \sqrt{1.5}\left(\mathrm{~V}_{0}-1\right)=3-\mathrm{V}_{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \mathrm{V}_{0}=\frac{3+\sqrt{1.5}}{\sqrt{1.5}+1}=\text { less than } 2 \mathrm{~V}
$$

question_text:
The frequency response $\mathrm{H}(\mathrm{f})$ of a linear timeinvariant system has magnitude as shown in the figure.

Statement I: The system is necessarily a pure delay system for inputs which are bandlimited to $-\alpha \leq f \leq \alpha$.

Statement II: For any wide-sense stationary input process with power spectral density $S_{x}(\mathrm{f})$, the output power spectral density $S_{Y}(\mathrm{f})$ obeys $S_{Y}(f)=S_{X}(f)$ for $-\alpha \leq f \leq \alpha$.


Which one of the following combinations is true?

[image1]

(a) Statement I is correct, Statement II is correct

(b) Statement I is correct, Statement II is incorrect

(c) Statement I is incorrect, Statement II is correct

(d) Statement I is incorrect, Statement II is incorrect
solution_text:
(c)
[image1]

For the system to be delay system,

$$
\begin{aligned}
y(t) & =x\left(t-t_{d}\right) \\
y(F) & =e^{-J \omega t_{d}} \times(F) \\
\Rightarrow \quad H(F) & =\frac{Y(F)}{X(F)}=e^{-J \omega t_{d}} \\
\Rightarrow \quad T F & \text { of delay system }
\end{aligned}
$$
- Here given system is constant, hence this is not delay system, therefore statement-I is In correct
- $S_{y}(f)=S_{x}(f) .|H(f)|^{2}$

and $|H(f)|=1$ (given)

Hence, $S_{y}(f)=S_{x}(f)$ for $-\alpha \leq f \leq \alpha$

Statement - II is correct.

subject: Technical
question_text:
Consider the following partial differential equation (PDE)

$$
a \frac{\partial^{2} f(x, y)}{\partial x^{2}}+b \frac{\partial^{2} f(x, y)}{\partial y^{2}}=f(x, y)
$$

where $a$ and b are distinct positive real numbers. Select the combination(s) of values of the real parameters $\xi$ and $\eta$ such that $f(x, y)=e^{(\xi x+)}$ is a solution of the given PDE.
(a) $\xi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \mathrm{a}}}, \eta-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \mathrm{~b}}}$
(b) $\xi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\mathrm{a}}}, \eta=0$
(c) $\xi=0, \eta=0$
(d) $\xi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\mathrm{a}}}, \eta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\mathrm{b}}}$

\section*{
solution_text:
(a, b)}

Given: $f(x, y)=e^{(\xi x+n y)}$

$\frac{\partial f(x, y)}{\partial x}=\xi \cdot e^{(\xi x+\eta y)}$

$\frac{\partial^{2} f(x, y)}{\partial x^{2}}=\xi^{2} \cdot e^{(\xi x+n y)}$

Similarly, $\frac{\partial^{2} f(x, y)}{\partial y^{2}}=\eta^{2} \cdot e^{(\xi x+n y)}$

Now, as given

$a \frac{\partial^{2} f(x, y)}{\partial x^{2}}+b \frac{\partial^{2} f(x, y)}{\partial y^{2}}=f(x, y)$

or

$a \times \xi^{2} e^{(\xi x+n y)}+b \times \eta^{2} e^{(\xi x+n y)}=e^{(\xi x+n y)}$

$\left(\mathrm{a} \cdot \xi^{2}+\mathrm{b} \cdot \eta^{2}\right)=1$

Thus, $\left(\xi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \mathrm{a}}}, \eta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \mathrm{~b}}}\right)$

subject: Technical
question_text:
Select the correct statement(s) regarding CMOS implementation of NOT gates.

(a) Noise Margin High ( $\mathrm{NM}_{\mathrm{H}}$ ) is always equal to the Noise Margin Low ( $\mathrm{NM}_{\mathrm{L}}$ ), irrespective of the sizing of transistors.

(b) Dynamic power consumption during switching is zero.

(c) For a logical high input under steady state, the nMOSFET is in the linear regime of operation.

(d) Mobility of electrons never influences the switching speed of the NOT gate.
solution_text:
(c)

(a) $\mathrm{NM}_{\mathrm{H}}$ will not be always equal to $\mathrm{NM}_{\mathrm{L}}$ because it depends on transistors parameters like size.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{NM}_{\mathrm{H}}=\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{IL}}-\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{OL}} \\
& \mathrm{NM}_{\mathrm{L}}=\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{OH}}-\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{IH}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Condition for $\mathrm{NM}_{\mathrm{H}}=\mathrm{NM}_{\mathrm{L}}$ : When $\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{TN}}=\left|\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{TP}}\right|$

$\& V_{I P}=\frac{V_{D D}}{2}$

If $\frac{K_{p}}{K_{n}}>1$ then $N M_{H} \neq N M_{L}$

(b) Due to capacitive leading of stage, dynamic power consumption during switching will not be zero.

(c) For $V_{D D}-\left|V_{T P}\right| \leq V_{\text {in }} \leq V_{D D}$ [Iogic high input]

PMOS $\rightarrow$ cut off

NMOS $\rightarrow$ Linear

(d) M dbility of electrons influences the switching speed because

Propagation delay $=\tau_{p}=\frac{\tau_{\mathrm{PLH}}+\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{PHL}}}{2}$

[image1]

Therefore (c) is only correct

subject: Technical
question_text:
Let $\mathrm{H}(\mathrm{X})$ denote the entropy of a discrete random variable $X$ taking K possible distinct real values. Which of the following statements is/are necessarily true?
(a) $H(X) \leq \log _{2} K$ bits
(b) $H(X) \leq H(2 X)$
(c) $H(X) \leq H\left(X^{2}\right)$
(d) $\mathrm{H}(\mathrm{X}) \leq \mathrm{H}\left(2^{\mathrm{X}}\right)$
solution_text:
(a, b, d)

Let $y=x^{2}$

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline$X$ & $Y$ & $P(Y)$ \\
\hline-1 & 1 & $1 / 4$ \\
\hline 0 & 0 & $1 / 2$ \\
\hline 1 & 1 & $1 / 4$ \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline$Y$ & 0 & 1 \\
\hline$P(Y)$ & $1 / 2$ & $1 / 2$ \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

$$
H\left(X^{2}\right)=H(Y)=\Sigma P_{Y}\left(Y_{i}\right) \log _{2} \frac{1}{P_{Y}\left(Y_{i}\right)}
$$

$$
=\frac{1}{2} \log _{2} 2+\frac{1}{2} \log _{2} 2=1 \mathrm{bit} / \text { symbol }
$$

$H(X)=\frac{1}{4} \log _{2} 4+\frac{1}{2} \log _{2} 2+\frac{1}{4} \log _{2} 4=1.5 \mathrm{bit} /$ symbol

$$
H(X)>H\left(X^{2}\right)
$$

Hence option (c) is not correct

question_text:

$\oint_{C} \frac{2^{z}}{z^{2}-1} d z=-i \pi A ï¼Œ$

solution_text:
$(1 / 2=0.5)$

$$
\oint_{C} \frac{2^{z}}{z^{2}-1} d z
$$

Roots $(z-1)(z+1)=0$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& z= \pm 1 \\

question_text:
The function $f(x)=8 \log _{e} x-x^{2}+3$ attains its minimum over the interval [1, e] at $x=$ $\qquad$ .

(Here $\log _{e} \mathrm{x}$ is the natural logarithm of x .)
(a) 2
(b) 1
(c) e
(d) $\frac{1+e}{2}$
solution_text:
(b)

$$
f(x)=8 \log _{e} x-x^{2}+3 \text { when } x \in[1, e]
$$

Differentiating both side,

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(x) & =\frac{8}{x}-2 x=0 ; \text { where } x>0 \\
f^{\prime}(x) & =0 \\
\frac{8}{x}-2 x & =0 \quad \Rightarrow 8-2 x^{2}=0 \\
2 x^{2} & =8 \\
x^{2} & =4 \\
x & = \pm 2
\end{aligned}
$$
$x=2$ which is in $\in[1, \mathrm{e}]$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f^{\prime \prime}(x)=\frac{-8}{x^{2}}-2 \\
& f^{\prime \prime}(2)=-6<0
\end{aligned}
$$

$\therefore \mathrm{f}(\mathrm{x})$ is maximum for $\mathrm{x}=2$

$\therefore$ Minimum of $f(x)$ will be in $[1$, e]

$=\min [f(1), f(e)]$

$$
f(e)=8 \ell \text { ne }-e^{2}+3=3.61
$$

Hence, minimum value of $f(x)$ occurs at $x=1$

question_text:
Consider the following series:

$$
\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{n^{d}}{c^{n}}
$$

For which of the following combinations of $\mathrm{c}, \mathrm{d}$ values does this series converge?
(a) $c=1, d=-1$
(b) $c=2, d=1$
(c) $\mathrm{c}=0.5, \mathrm{~d}=-10$
(d) $c=1, d=-2$

\section*{
solution_text:
(b, d)}

$\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{n^{d}}{c^{n}}$ series converage for

Ratio test $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{U_{n+1}}{U_{n}}$

Option (b) c $=2, d=1 \Rightarrow \Sigma U_{n} \sum U_{n}=\sum \frac{n}{2^{n}}$

$\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{U_{n+1}}{U_{n}}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{(n+1)}{2^{n+1}} \times \frac{2^{n}}{n}=\frac{1}{2}<1$



Option (a) c = 1, d $=-1$

$\Rightarrow \sum \mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{n}}=\sum \frac{\mathrm{n}^{-1}}{\mathrm{I}^{\mathrm{n}}}=\sum \frac{1}{\mathrm{n}}$

$\sum \frac{1}{n}$ is divergent by p -test

Option (c) $c=0.5, d=-10$

$\Rightarrow \sum \mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{n}}=\sum \frac{\mathrm{n}^{-10}}{\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{\mathrm{n}}}$

$\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{U_{n+1}}{U_{n}}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{(n+1)^{-10}}{\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n+1}} \times \frac{(1 / 2)^{n}}{n^{-10}}=2>1$

Divergent by ratio test.

Option (d) c $=1, d=-2$

$\Rightarrow \sum U_{n}=\sum \frac{\mathrm{n}^{-2}}{1^{\mathrm{n}}}=\sum \frac{1}{\mathrm{n}^{2}}$

$\therefore \quad \sum \frac{1}{\mathrm{n}^{2}}$ is convergent by p-test

$\because \quad \sum \frac{1}{\mathrm{np}} \mathrm{p}>1$.

Linearity:

$\mathrm{ax}_{1}(\mathrm{t})+\mathrm{bx}_{2}(\mathrm{t}) \xrightarrow{\text { sys }} \mathrm{ay}_{1}(\mathrm{t})+\mathrm{by}_{2}(\mathrm{t})$

Time - Invariant:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x\left(t+t_{0}\right) \xrightarrow{\text { sys }} y\left(t+t_{0}\right) \\
& S_{1}: x\left(t+t_{0}\right)=\sin \left(t+t_{0}\right) \xrightarrow{s_{1}} \sin \left(-\left(t+t_{0}\right)\right) \\
& \because \sin (-t)=-\sin (t)
\end{aligned}
$$

May be LTI sys

LTI sys

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{S}_{3}: \xrightarrow{\sin \left(\mathrm{t}+\mathrm{t}_{0}\right)} \rightarrow \mathrm{S}_{3} \rightarrow \sin \left(2\left(\mathrm{t}+\mathrm{t}_{0}\right)\right. \\
& \because \sin \left(2 \mathrm{t}+\mathrm{t}_{0}\right) \neq \sin \left(2\left(\mathrm{t}+\mathrm{t}_{0}\right)\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Time-variant (Not LTI sys)

[image2]

Linear and Time - variant (not LTI)

A state transition diagram with states $\mathrm{A}, \mathrm{B}$ and C , and transition probabilities $\mathrm{p}_{1}, \mathrm{p}_{2}, \ldots, \mathrm{p}_{7}$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
y & =A+\bar{B}=\overline{\bar{A}} \cdot B \\
f(A, B) & =A+\bar{B} \\
f(0, B) & =0+\bar{B}=\bar{B} \Rightarrow \text { NOT Gate } \\
f(A, \bar{B}) & =A+\overline{\bar{B}}=A+B \Rightarrow \text { OR Gate } \\
f(0, f(A, \bar{B})) & =0+(\overline{A+B}) \Rightarrow \text { NOR Gate } \\
f(\bar{A}, B) & =\bar{A}+\bar{B}=\overline{A \cdot B} \Rightarrow \text { NAND Gate } \\
f(0, f(\bar{A}, B)) & =0+(\overline{\overline{A \cdot B}})=A \cdot B \Rightarrow \text { AND Gate }
\end{aligned}
$$

question_text:
Twolinear time-invariant systems with transfer functions

$G_{1}(s)=\frac{10}{s^{2}+s+1}$ and $G_{2}(s)=\frac{10}{s^{2}+s \sqrt{10}+10}$

have unit step responses $\mathrm{y}_{1}(\mathrm{t})$ and $\mathrm{y}_{2}(\mathrm{t})$, respectively. Which of the following statements is/are true?

(a) $y_{1}(t)$ and $y_{2}(t)$ have the same percentage peak overshoot.

(b) $y_{1}(t)$ and $y_{2}(t)$ have the same steady-state value

(c) $y_{1}(t)$ and $y_{2}(t)$ have the same damped frequency of oscillation.

(d) $y_{1}(t)$ and $y_{2}(t)$ have the same $2 \%$ settling time.
solution_text:
(a)

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{G}_{1}(\mathrm{~s}) & =\frac{10}{\mathrm{~s}^{2}+\mathrm{s}+1} \\
\omega_{\mathrm{n}_{1}}^{2} & =1 \\
2 \xi_{1} \times 1 & =1 \\
\xi_{1} & =1 / 2 \\
\mathrm{G}_{2}(\mathrm{~s}) & =\frac{10}{\mathrm{~s}^{2}+\mathrm{s} \sqrt{10}+10} \\
\omega_{\mathrm{n}_{2}}^{2} & =10 \\
2 \times \xi_{2} \times \sqrt{10} & =\sqrt{10} \\
\xi_{2} & =1 / 2
\end{aligned}
$$
$\because \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{p}}$ depends on $\xi$ only

$\mathrm{y}_{1}(\mathrm{t})$ \& $\mathrm{y}_{2}(\mathrm{t})$ have same percentage peak overshoot.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega_{\mathrm{d}_{1}} & =\omega_{\mathrm{n}_{1}} \sqrt{1-\xi_{1}^{2}} \\
\Rightarrow \quad \omega_{\mathrm{d}_{1}} & \neq \omega_{\mathrm{d}_{2}} \quad \because \quad \omega_{\mathrm{n}_{1}} \neq \omega_{\mathrm{n}_{2}}

question_text:
A waveguide consists of two infinite parallel plates (perfect conductors) at a separation of $10^{-4} \mathrm{~cm}$, with air as the dielectric. Assume the speed of light in air to be $3 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. The frequency/frequencies of TM waves which can propagate in this waveguide is/are $\qquad$ .
(a) $6 \times 10^{15} \mathrm{~Hz}$
(b) $0.5 \times 10^{12} \mathrm{~Hz}$
(c) $8 \times 10^{14} \mathrm{~Hz}$
(d) $1 \times 10^{13} \mathrm{~Hz}$
solution_text:
(a, c)

Cut-off frequency.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{c}} & =\frac{\mathrm{c}}{2 \mathrm{a}} \quad(\mathrm{m}=1) \\
& =\frac{3 \times 10^{8}}{2 \times 10^{-4} \times 10^{-2}} \because \mathrm{a}=10^{-4} \mathrm{~cm} \text { (given) } \\
& =1.5 \times 10^{14} \mathrm{~Hz} \\
\mathrm{f} & >\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{c}} \text { will only propagate } \\
\Rightarrow \mathrm{A} & \& C \text { will propage }
\end{aligned}
$$

solution_text:
(0.59)}

Given

$$
\begin{aligned}
\delta_{n}(x) & =R \tau_{n}=10^{20} \mathrm{e}^{-|x| \ell_{n}} \cdot \tau_{n} \\
\delta_{\mathrm{n}}\left(\ell_{n}\right) & =10^{20} \mathrm{e}^{-1} \tau_{n} \\
\text { for } \quad \ell_{n} & \leq \mathrm{x} \leq 2 \ell_{\mathrm{n}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Continuity equation is given by

$D_{n} \frac{\partial^{2} \delta_{n}}{\delta x^{2}}+G-R=0$

$G \& R$ both are zero - for $\left[\ell_{n} \leq x \leq 2 \ell_{n}\right]$

Hence Equation (i) reduced to $D_{n} \frac{\partial^{n} \delta_{n}}{\partial x^{2}}=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad \delta_{\mathrm{n}}(\mathrm{x})=\mathrm{Ax}+\mathrm{B}$

For calculating A \& B we use Boundary condition

$$
\begin{align*}
\delta_{n}\left(2 \ell_{n}\right) & =0 \quad \Rightarrow A=\frac{-B}{2 \ell_{n}} \\
\therefore \quad \delta_{n}(x) & =\frac{-B}{2 \ell_{n}} x+B=B\left[1-\frac{x}{2 \ell_{n}}\right] . \tag{iii}
\end{align*}
$$

At $x=\ell_{n}$

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\Rightarrow & 10^{20} \mathrm{e}^{-1} \tau_{n}=\mathrm{B}\left[1-\frac{\ell_{n}}{2 \ell_{n}}\right] \\
\Rightarrow & B=2 \times 10^{20} \mathrm{e}^{-1} \tau_{\mathrm{n}} \\
\therefore & \delta_{n}(\mathrm{x})=2 \times 10^{20} \mathrm{e}^{-1} \tau_{n}\left[1-\frac{\mathrm{x}}{2 \ell_{n}}\right]
\end{array}
$$

for $\quad \ell_{n} \leq x \leq 2 \ell_{n}$

Electron diffusion current density is given by

$\left|J_{n}\right|_{\text {diff }}=q D_{n} \frac{d \eta}{d x}=q D_{n} \times 2 \times 10^{20} \times e^{-1} \times \tau_{n}\left[0-\frac{1}{2 \ell_{n}}\right]$

$=\frac{1.6 \times 10^{-19} \times \ell_{\mathrm{n}}^{2} \times 2 \times 10^{20} \times \mathrm{e}^{-1}}{2 \ell_{\mathrm{n}}}$

$=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \times \ell_{\mathrm{n}} \times 10^{20} \times \mathrm{e}^{-1}$

$=1.6 \times 10 \times 1 \times 10^{-4} \times \mathrm{e}^{-1}$

$=0.59 \mathrm{~mA} / \mathrm{cm}^{2}$

question_text:
The transistion diagram of a discrete memoryless channel with three input symbols and three output symbols is shown in the figure. The transition probabilities are as marked.

The parameter $\alpha$ lies in the interval $[0.25,1]$. The value of $\alpha$ for which the capacity of this channel is maximized, is $\qquad$ (rounded off to two decimal places).

[image1]
solution_text:
(1)

$\alpha \in[0.25,1]$

[image1]

$I(x: y)=H(y)-H(y / x)$

where,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& H(y / x)=\sum_{i=1}^{3} \sum_{j=1}^{3} P\left(x_{i}, y_{i}\right) \log _{2} P\left(y_{i} / x_{i}\right) \\
& {[P(y / x)]=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1-\alpha & \alpha & 0 \\
0 & 1-\alpha & \alpha \\
\alpha & 0 & 1-\alpha
\end{array}\right]} \\
& {[P(x / y)]=[P(x)]_{d} \cdot[P(y / x)]} \\
& {[P(x)]_{d}=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1 / 3 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 / 3 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1 / 3
\end{array}\right]} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad[P(x, y)]=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
(1-\alpha) / 3 & \alpha / 3 & 0 \\
0 & (1-\alpha) / 3 & \alpha / 3 \\
\alpha / 3 & 0 & (1-\alpha) / 3
\end{array}\right] \\
& H(y / x)=-\left\{\frac{(1-\alpha)}{3} \log _{2}(1-\alpha)+\frac{\alpha}{3} \log _{2}(\alpha)\right\} \times 3 \\
& =-\left\{(1-\alpha) \log _{2}(1-\alpha)+\alpha \log _{2}(\alpha)\right\} \\
& I(x ; y)=H(y)-H(y / x) \\
& =H(y)+(1-\alpha) \log _{2}(1-\alpha)+\alpha \log _{2}(\alpha) \\
& C_{s}=\max \{(x ; y)\} \\
& =\max \{H(y)\}+\alpha \log _{2}(\alpha)+(1-\alpha) \log _{2}(1-\alpha) \\
& =\log _{2}^{3}+\alpha \log _{2}(\alpha)+(1-\alpha) \log _{2}(1-\alpha)
\end{aligned}
$$

[image2]

Channel capacity will be maximum for $\alpha=0$ or $\alpha=1$. Otherwise it will be lesser.

$$

Problem of error $=P_{e}=P\left(X_{A}\right) P_{\text {eXA }}+P\left(X_{B}\right) P_{\text {exB }}$

$P_{\text {exA }}=$ Problem of error when $X_{A}$ is transmitted

$P_{\text {exB }}=$ Problem of error when $X_{B}$ is transmitted

For decision making

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \begin{array}{c|c}
\mathrm{Y} \longrightarrow \\
\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{th}} & \mathrm{ML} \\
\text { Detector }
\end{array} \longrightarrow \\
& Y=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
X_{A} ; \text { If } Y<V_{\text {th }} \\
X_{B} ; \text { If } Y>V_{\text {th }}
\end{array}\right. \\
& P_{e}=P\left(X_{A}\right) P\left(Y>V_{\text {th }}\right) \\
& =P\left(X_{B}\right) P\left(Y<V_{\text {th }}\right) \\
& P_{e}=P\left(X_{A}\right) \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-(Y+1)} d y+P\left(X_{B}\right) \int_{-\infty}^{0} e^{Y-1} d y \\
& =P\left(X_{A}\right) \cdot e^{-1}+P\left(X_{B}\right) e^{-1} \\
& =e^{-1}\left[P\left(X_{A}\right)+P\left(X_{B}\right)\right] \\
& =\mathrm{e}^{-1} \\
& =0.367
\end{aligned}
$$

solution_text:

Again, $M S Q\left[Q_{e}\right]=E\left[\left(X-X_{q}\right)^{2}\right]$

Quantization noise power $=\mathrm{N}_{\text {ã€‚ }}$

for $-2 \leq x \leq 0 \Rightarrow N_{Q}=\int_{-2}^{0}(x-\beta)^{2} \times\left(\frac{1}{4} x+\frac{1}{2}\right) d x$

$$

& =\int_{-2}^{0}\left[x^{2}+\beta^{2}-2 x \beta\right]\left[\frac{x}{4}+\frac{1}{2}\right] d x \\

$\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{Q}}$ to be minimum:

Similarly for ' $\alpha$ '

question_text:
In an electrostatic field, the electric displacement density vector, $\vec{D}$, is given by

$$
\vec{D}(x, y, z)=\left(x^{3} \vec{i}+y^{3} \vec{j}+x y^{2} \vec{k}\right) C / m^{2}
$$

where $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{i}}, \overrightarrow{\mathrm{j}}, \overrightarrow{\mathrm{k}}$ are the unit vectors along $\mathrm{x}$-axis, y-axis, and z-axis, respectively. Consider a cubical region $\mathrm{R}$ centered at the origin with each side of length $1 \mathrm{~m}$, and vertices at $( \pm 0.5 \mathrm{~m}, \pm 0.5 \mathrm{~m}, \pm 0.5 \mathrm{~m}$ ). The electric charge enclosed within $R$ is $\qquad$ $\mathrm{C}$ (rounded off to two decimal places).
solution_text:
(0.5)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \overrightarrow{\mathrm{D}}(\mathrm{x}, \mathrm{y}, \mathrm{z})=\left(\mathrm{x}^{3} \vec{i}+\mathrm{y}^{3} \vec{j}+x y^{2} \vec{k}\right) c / m^{2} \\
& Q_{\text {enc. }}=\int_{v} \rho_{v} \cdot d V=\int(\nabla \cdot \vec{D}) d V \\
& \nabla \cdot \vec{D}=3 x^{2}+3 y^{2} \\
& d V=d x d y d z \\
& \therefore Q_{\text {enc. }}=\int_{v} 3\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right) d x d y d z \\
& =3\left[\int_{-0.5}^{0.5} x^{2} d x \int_{-0.5}^{0.5} d y \int_{-0.5}^{0.5} d z+\int_{-0.5}^{0.5} d x \int_{-0.5}^{0.5} y^{2} d y \int_{-0.5}^{0.5} d z\right] \\
& =3\left[\left.\frac{x^{3}}{3}\right|_{-0.5} ^{0.5} \times 1 \times 1+\left.\frac{y^{3}}{3}\right|_{-0.5} ^{0.5} \times 1 \times 1\right] \\
& =0.25+0.25 \\
& Q_{\text {enc }}=0.5 C
\end{aligned}
$$
